thread.title: Royals showing Jays' Price plenty of respect
thread.title_full: Royals showing Jays' Price plenty of respect

title: Royals showing Jays' Price plenty of respect
text:
Blue Jays blast Royals to force Game 6 KANSAS CITY - 
It may have looked like they got the best of David Price for one night — one inning, truthfully — but the Kansas City Royals aren’t banking on the same thing happening with an American League pennant on the line here Friday night. 
They couldn’t care less about Price’s 0-7 record as a starter in the post-season or a lick about the perception that they knocked the Jays celebrated starter around to finish off the home sweep of the first two games of the ALCS. 
Those who stood in the Royals batters’ box for the first six innings of last Saturday’s contest weren’t exactly gloating about the five hits they touched Price for on the way to a tough 6-3 loss for the Jays. Nor were they expecting to benefit from similar good fortune in the first of two potential elimination games this weekend at Kauffman Stadium. 
“He gave up a hit on the first pitch and then he didn’t give up another hit until the seventh inning,” Royals manager Ned Yost said on Thursday as his team prepared to face the ace the would-be ace for a second time in the series. “He’s a guy that’s in the top five in the voting for Cy Young. He’s a tough matchup. 
“We’re just going to have to hope that we can take advantage of mistakes, if he makes any, and just keep battling.” 
When asked what his Royals hitters can take away from that decisive seventh inning, Yost didn’t flinch: “Nothing.” 
Perhaps that’s why Yost has been such a solid manager and his player’s — especially at the plate — are so mentally strong. The Royals weren’t going to refund the win, but they know that some nights getting bat on ball can benefit from some good fortune. 
The skipper wouldn’t get any argument from those in the Kansas City batting order, either. To a man, the hitters that got to Price in Game 2 knew they didn’t necessarily smack around a pitcher poised to be a $200-million man in the off-season. 
After surrendering a single on his first pitch of the game, Price retired 18 Royals in a row, was staked to a 3-0 lead and looked destined for his first career playoff “W” as a starter. 
What happened next will make for a long winter for all involved if the Jays don’t capture the next two in K.C. 
The Ryan Goins botch of a routine pop up started it and four hits to the subsequent six batters sealed it. 
“I don’t even know how to explain (what happened), quite honestly,” Royals first baseman Eric Hosmer said of what seemed an unlikely rally given how effective Price had been. “The guy was still nasty, even in the seventh. He was doing a good job of working the outside of the plate with us. We just tried to stay patient.” 
Like most MLB teams, the Royals take pride in the video work they put in on pitchers and upon further review of Game 2, they found nothing to think they have the 30-year-old left-hander solved. They certainly didn’t rock Price, more accurately they stayed patient in working the count in mentally tough at-bats. 
On Thursday here, Price gave credit to those Royals hitters, in particular praising Lorenzo Cain’s single that kept the inning going as a “good piece of hitting.” 
Based on what they saw in Game 2, the Royals certainly don’t believe Price’s 1-2 record and 7.02 earned run average this post season is representative of what he can do. In fact, if Price is on again, suddenly it may be the Royals who tighten up. 
If the Jays can ride the starter that helped them get to the playoffs in the first place, they will move onto Marcus Stroman, the man who threatened to replace him as the ace late in the season. Back at Kauffman Stadium, though, the Royals hitters are at their peck-away-at-you best. 
“It’s a tough lineup, they use their speed,” Price said of the Royals. “They’re not going to beat themselves and that’s what you’ve got to do at this point of the season. 
“This is the same situation we were in against Texas in the Division Series. This team does a very good job of focussing on the task at hand. That’s what this team has done an extremely good job of ever since I’ve been here. It’s been pretty impressive.” 
Other than the end result in Game 2, that’s about how the Kansas City Royals view David Price as well.
